Representations = root data

Mar 26, 2020

Our goal in this post is to describe a very nice result due to Kazhdan, Larsen, and Varshavsky. We’ll work over an algebraically closed field of characteristic . Let be a reductive algebraic group, and fix a maximal torus . Fix a Borel subgroup . Let (resp. ) denote the lattice of weights (resp. coweights), and let (resp. ) denote the lattice of positive weights (resp. dominant coweights) determined by . We first notice that the simple coroots can be recovered from the partially ordered monoid : they are exactly the minimal nonzero elements. We’d next like to determine the simple roots from this. The roots are then given by the translates of the simple roots given by the action of . Similarly, the coroots are determined by the translates of the simple coroots given by the action of . We’re done!

The key result of the paper is:

Theorem: The semiring of finite-dimensional semisimple representations of determines the root datum of .

I guess the way I’ve been writing it (with coweights instead of weights), what we’re showing is that the semiring of finite-dimensional semisimple representations of the Langlands dual determines the root datum. Whoops. By the observation, it suffices to show that the semiring determines the partially ordered monoid .

Given , we can construct the irreducible representation of with highest weight . This gives a bijection between the dominant coweights of and irreducible objects of . Moreover, the monoid structure on can be recovered too: if and only if is the largest dominant coweight for which is an irreducible subquotient of .

The takeaway I’d like to state is the following. The Tannakian formalism allows us to reconstruct from (if is reductive, then this category is semisimple). One can extract , and this has “negative” elements (e.g., for a -representation). The theorem discussed here says that, in fact, if we look at equipped with a submonoid of “nonnegative” elements (i.e., the elements of which are actually representations of ), then we can still recover . There’s a general abstract way to encode “nonnegativity”: this is the notion of Bridgeland stability.

This is screaming out categorification: takes 1-categories to 0-categories, and Bridgeland stability/positivity allows us to “go back up one category level”. (I used the word “positivity” on purpose: this is closely related to the notion of positivity in algebraic geometry.) I haven’t really seen any place where this has been made precise, so I’ve worked out a precise version of this statement in some notes. I’ll try to discuss this in a future post.
